componenttext: Yes, I mean, that's encouraging for us. I mean, sometimes, it could take a little bit, right? I mean, I think there's -- right now in the market, it's pretty clear. It's primarily in the trucking and transportation sector. And it's not only that the freight volumes haven't grown to the levels we'd like them to, but there's definitely an oversupply of some trucks. So some of this might just take a little bit to bleed through the trucks that are sitting for these folks. And once those trucks are either -- either they're out of the system or they're being utilized, that's when we should start to see it help us in rental.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just on the used truck side. It sounds like the issue at this point is more of a volume than pricing. But does it tell you something that the pricing is low, but the volume's not moving? Like are we still in like price discovery and the pri
componenttext: Okay. And then just on the used truck side. It sounds like the issue at this point is more of a volume than pricing. But does it tell you something that the pricing is low, but the volume's not moving? Like are we still in like price discovery and the pricing needs to move lower for the volume to start moving?

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's a good question. It's hard to tell, right? I mean, we believe that at these prices, we are moving a good amount of volume. Also, in a market where if there's not a need for a truck lowering the price doesn't necessarily create that need. So w
componenttext: Well, that's a good question. It's hard to tell, right? I mean, we believe that at these prices, we are moving a good amount of volume. Also, in a market where if there's not a need for a truck lowering the price doesn't necessarily create that need. So we feel -- we really haven't dropped the price over the last several months and we've been able to move the volumes that we've needed to. So we think this is a reasonable level in terms of pricing. And even if you look at historical levels, when they come down, and we got to keep monitoring it.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: The volumes, yes. I'm saying the pricing. Pricing, we haven't lowered. Hang on. Dennis, go ahead.

componenttext: Scott, I just wanted to clarify that we sold 5,100 units in the second quarter. That's up 9% year-over-year. And tractors were up 13%. So the volume is moving.

componenttext: So then why are you lowering the volume expectations?

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Because again, our expectations coming in were higher. So we -- but still, what I'm saying is 9% up overall and then 13% on tractors. It's up year-over-year, it's just not at the same level that we had expected.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Right. We had expected to really be able to increase the volumes in the second half of the year, and we're not seeing the ability to do that.

componenttext: No, we're selling more -- we are selling some more in the wholesale market. I think -- our retail percentage is now about 68% versus last year, we were at 74%, 75%. So we are selling a little -- some more units in wholesale, which is partially what's driving down some of that pricing that we're seeing.

componenttext: Okay. Got you. That makes sense. And then as we look at your lease fleet growth, you're still getting some decent organic growth. componenttext: Yes, Kevin, it's Dennis. So 40% of our volume is coming from new to outsourcing customers. And that's up from about 1/3 last year. So we're encouraged by the trend.

componenttext: Robert or maybe this is for Dennis, but can you help us think about the redeployments of used vehicles into the lease fleet. What does the margin profile on a redeployment look like versus a new vehicle? And I would think that, that's going to push up the average age of the lease fleet. And that historically, there's been some margin impact for that. So how do we think about the margin profile of FMS going forward if there's more used equipment in the lease fleet versus newer equipment?

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Todd, I don't think -- I think, obviously, we're doing more redeployments. But I think in the big scheme of things, I don't think it's enough to move the needle a whole lot on margin. I think the key is really being able to continue to grow the fleet
componenttext: Yes, Todd, I don't think -- I think, obviously, we're doing more redeployments. But I think in the big scheme of things, I don't think it's enough to move the needle a whole lot on margin. I think the key is really being able to continue to grow the fleet and being able to continue as we -- because along with also bringing in some redeployments, we're also bringing in new equipment. I think it's just under 70% of what we're selling is with new equipment. Now it was 80-plus percent before. But you still got the vast majority of the units coming in that are still new equipment.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: No, no, I don't think so.

componenttext: Okay. And then I think I have most of this, but just to make sure that I'm clear on it. The reduction guidance at this point, I mean, it really feels like that the $0.20 that you took out of the back half of the year that, that's predominantly related to lower rental demand and then a smaller piece related to used vehicle volumes. If you can give us maybe the magnitude of the EPS that's related to those, I think that, that would be helpful. And then if you have anything in there for share buybacks kind of going the other way or anything that would be offsetting that, that could kind of help us think about some of the magnitude of the operational cut versus some other things going through in the back half of the year.

componenttext: I had a question, first question, on the level of vehicles redeployed. I think you said that's up roughly 2x in the quarter. I'm trying to get a sense if increased redeployments, if they hurt you in any way, if there's any like negative margin impact? Or if from a customer perspective, the customer would rather have a new vehicle versus used vehicle. I'm just trying to get my arms around if redeployments is potentially a headwind for you, if they're up moving forward.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, look, I think, Matt, that's a key part of our asset management strategy and it's one of the core competencies that we have. Our ability to take units that are in the rental fleet and idle for other reasons and be able to redeploy them into revenue-ear
componenttext: No, look, I think, Matt, that's a key part of our asset management strategy and it's one of the core competencies that we have. Our ability to take units that are in the rental fleet and idle for other reasons and be able to redeploy them into revenue-earning applications is a real important part of our business model. So net, it's definitely a positive in terms of overall returns for the company.

componenttext: Matt, it's John. As you look at the second quarter performance, about 1/3 of that improvement is operations and about 2/3 was the insurance side. That's a little bit more than what we saw in the first quarter, but we are seeing expanding margins in the business and you should expect that going forward.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttextpreview: I would tell you, we've had fairly good performance on the safety side. We could always look to get better and we'll continue to get better. But the majority of what we've seen this year is prior year development on our self-insurance reserves. And we've
componenttext: I would tell you, we've had fairly good performance on the safety side. We could always look to get better and we'll continue to get better. But the majority of what we've seen this year is prior year development on our self-insurance reserves. And we've seen that develop favorably for us. So looking ahead to predict that would be a little bit kind of shooting a dart in the dark there.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Fair enough. And then just last question. I think the number of vehicles serviced under your on-demand maintenance program, I think the total number was down on a year-over-year basis. I think it was up sequentially, but down year-over-year. I was j
componenttext: Okay. Fair enough. And then just last question. I think the number of vehicles serviced under your on-demand maintenance program, I think the total number was down on a year-over-year basis. I think it was up sequentially, but down year-over-year. I was just curious to hear if there's anything specific that drove the number lower and then how should we think about the potential growth of vehicles serviced in the second half of this year?

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Matt, it's Dennis. The -- there were 2 major customers we had who were not coming in for as much maintenance. And I think the driver of that was related to just fewer miles being driven as you look at the softness in the freight market. So I think th
componenttext: Yes, Matt, it's Dennis. The -- there were 2 major customers we had who were not coming in for as much maintenance. And I think the driver of that was related to just fewer miles being driven as you look at the softness in the freight market. So I think that was the driver. We actually have more customers coming on board. So we're still bullish on continuing to grow the volume. The other thing I'd add is that having on-demand maintenance has really enabled what we're doing with our more flexible lease products, our ChoiceLease products. And that's -- there's been some nice momentum there also.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: The next question comes from Brian Ossenbeck with JPMC.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Also had 2 quick ones here. One is for Dennis. You mentioned that 40% new business lease coming from customers, first-time outsourcing. I don't know if you could give us some clarity on what types of business these are, if there is some type of industry vertical that you found some success relative to last year in certain geographies. And then maybe are these a lot of singles and doubles in terms of size or are there any big, notable conversions that you've been able to bring into the fold this year?

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say that it's across all the verticals. I can't point to any vertical in particular that stands out. But what I would say is, it's really the secular trends we've been seeing, the complexity of the vehicles, the difficulty recruiting technici
componenttext: Yes, I would say that it's across all the verticals. I can't point to any vertical in particular that stands out. But what I would say is, it's really the secular trends we've been seeing, the complexity of the vehicles, the difficulty recruiting technicians. It keeps playing out. And we've got more and more customers coming our way because we're out there with the total cost of ownership tool that you saw at Investor Day. And you couple that now with the flexibility we have with ChoiceLease, it's really leading to quite a bit of interest when you put those together. So again, you're seeing the difficulty that customers have because of the secular trends. You put the TCO in front of them. They like the compelling math that we put in front of them. And then you're flexible with your offering, it's leading to a lot of interest from the do-it-yourself market folks.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a quick follow-up on the technician shortage side from Ryder's perspective. If you can just give us an update on where that stands. I know it's also a tough market, not just drivers, but technicians are in short supply.
componenttext: Okay. And just a quick follow-up on the technician shortage side from Ryder's perspective. If you can just give us an update on where that stands. I know it's also a tough market, not just drivers, but technicians are in short supply.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've got 3 sources for technicians that we have a lot of success with. First is with the trade schools. We have a great relationship. Next is we develop our own from the fuel island up. We've got a great training program that our folks take advantag
componenttext: Yes, we've got 3 sources for technicians that we have a lot of success with. First is with the trade schools. We have a great relationship. Next is we develop our own from the fuel island up. We've got a great training program that our folks take advantage of. And finally is we partnered with the U.S. Chamber of Commerce with the Hiring Our Heroes program. We've had a lot of success there. So I'd say it's between those 3 sources. We're good at this. We're able to meet the demand that we see.

And then just the overall, the global interest rate environment has changed. It's come down, which does adversely impact our pension. headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ben, it's Dennis. There's interest is what I can say. As you have customers who want to own their vehicles, there's interest in getting maintenance help. And so we're seeing a lot of interest, a lot of demand that's out there. I'd add to that our flexibil
componenttext: Ben, it's Dennis. There's interest is what I can say. As you have customers who want to own their vehicles, there's interest in getting maintenance help. And so we're seeing a lot of interest, a lot of demand that's out there. I'd add to that our flexibility around being willing to do maintenance on-site, at the customer site or to do it mobile-ly is a nice feature that we have for customers who want more flexibility around the maintenance. So I can tell you, there's a lot of activity out there with people who are looking for help on maintenance. And I'd add to that, it leads to selling up where once they're doing maintenance with us, and the question is, can you help us from a lease point of view, and you get into the ChoiceLease products. So can we continue it? All I can tell you is the interest is strong.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Good. And then the last one, as we start to look toward 2017, some of the preliminary forecast for Class 8 sales and build are still down 10% to 15% year-over-year. So what's -- standing here today, what's the level of confidence that, I mean, you've referenced the 40% new outsourcing number quite a bit. What's the level of confidence that -- in still a declining Class 8 production environment next year that you can still generate positive lease fleet growth?

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we feel pretty confident. I think given the -- our ability to, as Dennis pointed out, use the total cost of ownership tool to help articulate the value prop for our services. The additional marketing efforts we've had. In addition to that, th
componenttext: Yes, I think we feel pretty confident. I think given the -- our ability to, as Dennis pointed out, use the total cost of ownership tool to help articulate the value prop for our services. The additional marketing efforts we've had. In addition to that, the new products, I mean, Dennis alluded to it, but the ChoiceLease Preventive, ChoiceLease On-Demand, these are just additional products now that are specifically targeted at the ownership market. And we've already had some success with them. We have customers that otherwise would not have leased and would not have come to Ryder that are now coming to us because we're offering these. So we think the ability to take those additional products to leverage the progress we've made in sales and marketing are really going to help us continue to drive growth even in an environment like that.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Ryder System, Inc.'s Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, please disconnect at this time. I would like introduce Mr. Bob Bru
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Ryder System, Inc.'s Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, please disconnect at this time. 
I would like introduce Mr. Bob Brunn, Vice President, Corporate Strategy and Investor Relations for Ryder. Mr. Brunn, you may now begin.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much. Good morning, and welcome to Ryder's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. I'd like to remind you that during this presentation, you'll hear some forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation R
componenttext:
Thanks very much. Good morning, and welcome to Ryder's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. I'd like to remind you that during this presentation, you'll hear some forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements are based on management's current expectations and are subject to uncertainty and changes in circumstances. Actual results may differ materially from these expectations due to changes in economic, business, competitive, market, political and regulatory factors. More detailed information about these factors is contained in this morning's earnings release and in Ryder's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
This conference call also includes certain non-GAAP financial measures. You may find reconciliations of each non-GAAP measure to the nearest GAAP measure in the written presentation accompanying this call, which is available on our website at investors.ryder.com. 
Presenting on today's call are Robert Sanchez, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Art Garcia, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Additionally, Dennis Cooke, President of Global Fleet Management Solutions; John Diez, President of Dedicated Transportation Solutions; and Steve Sensing, President of Global Supply Chain Solutions, are on the call today and available for questions following the presentation. With that, let me turn it over to Robert.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. This morning, we'll recap our third quarter 2016 results, review the asset management area and discuss the current outlook for our business. Then we'll open the call for questions. With that, let's turn
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. This morning, we'll recap our third quarter 2016 results, review the asset management area and discuss the current outlook for our business. Then we'll open the call for questions. 
With that, let's turn to an overview of our third quarter results. Comparable earnings per share from continuing operations were at $1.67 for the third quarter 2016, down 4% from the prior year. Third quarter 2016 comparable results exclude $0.08 of nonoperating pension cost. Last year's comparable earnings excluded $0.05 of nonoperating pension cost and $0.01 in pension-related benefits. 
Our Q3 results were within our comparable forecast range of $1.65 to $1.72, reflecting continued strength in our contractual businesses and commercial rental performance in line with our expectations for demand and pricing. In addition, favorable overhead performance helped to mitigate the impact of lower-than-expected used vehicle sales volumes. Operating revenue, which excludes fuel and subcontracted transportation revenue, grew by 3% to a record $1.5 billion for the third quarter and was higher in all business segments despite rental revenue being down 14%. Excluding the impact of foreign exchange, operating revenue increased by 4%. Total revenue increased by 3% and was impacted by the lower fuel cost passed through to customers. 
Page 5 includes some additional financial information for the third quarter. The average number of diluted shares outstanding for the quarter was unchanged versus last year at 53.3 million shares. We began repurchasing shares under the current 2 million share anti-dilutive repurchase program in the second quarter. The plan allows for purchase of up to 1.5 million shares issued to employees after December 1, 2015, and another 500,000 shares from the former plan that were not repurchased prior to expiration. 
During the quarter, we brought -- we bought approximately 58,000 shares at an average price of $64.59. For the program to date, we've purchased approximately 380,000 shares at an average price of $67.52. Excluding pension costs and other items, the comparable tax rate was 35.7% for the third quarter 2016, up 40 basis points from 35.3% in the prior year.
Page 6 highlights key financial statistics on a year-to-date basis. Operating revenue grew 5% to $4.3 billion. Comparable earnings per share from continuing operations were $4.35, down 3% from last year. The spread between adjusted return on capital and cost of capital decreased to 100 basis points, down from 140 basis points in the prior year, driven primarily by lower performance in used vehicle sales and commercial rental. For the full year 2016, we now expect this spread to be 90 basis points compared to our prior forecast of 100 basis points, reflecting lower expected used vehicle sales performance.
I'll turn now to Page 7 and discuss some key trends we saw in the business segments during the quarter. Fleet Management Solutions operating revenue, which excludes fuel, grew 1% as higher contractual revenue was largely offset by lower rental revenue. Lease revenue increased 7% due to fleet growth and higher rates on replacement vehicles, reflecting their higher cost. The lease fleet, excluding U.K. trailers, increased by 2,200 vehicles sequentially and by 5,200 vehicles year-to-date. Included in the lease fleet are a higher number of vehicles that are being prepared for sale. 
Excluding these vehicles for more relevant comparison to our forecast, the lease fleet grew by approximately 700 vehicles sequentially and 3,700 vehicles year-to-date, which keeps us on track to achieve our full year growth forecast of 4,000 vehicles. Full service lease continues to benefit from favorable outsourcing trends as well as our sales and marketing initiatives. So far this year, approximately 40% of our new lease sales came from customers new to outsourcing, up from about 1/3 last year.
Contract maintenance revenue increased 3%. The average contract maintenance fleet grew by 8,200 vehicles from the prior year, reflecting new customer wins and decreased by 100 vehicles sequentially. Contract-related maintenance revenue was up 5% from the prior year. Included in contract-related maintenance are 8,000 vehicles serviced during the quarter under on-demand maintenance agreements. This decrease of 2% from the prior year is due to lower volumes from trucking customers, but up sequentially 5%. Commercial rental revenue was down 14% for the quarter. Global rental demand was down by 13%, driven primarily by lower demand for tractors. Global pricing was flat for the quarter as expected. 
Our centralized asset management team executed effectively on our plan to reduce the rental fleet in light of softer demand by both redeploying vehicles into lease contracts and making vehicles available for sale. 
As a result of these actions, the average fleet decreased by 13% year-over-year. The ending rental fleet was down 2% sequentially from the second quarter and down 13% or 5,800 vehicles year-over-year. Vehicles redeployed into other applications were up significantly year-to-date. Redeployment activity reduced the amount of capital needed to fulfill new customer contracts, which benefited cash flow. Rental utilization on power units was up -- was 76.7%, up 30 basis points year-over-year. This is a significant improvement in year-over-year rental utilization comparisons versus those seen in the first half, reflecting actions that we took during the first half of the year to rightsize the rental fleet. 
Used vehicle results for the quarter were down year-over-year due to lower used vehicle pricing, primarily on tractors and lower volumes. I'll discuss those results separately in a few minutes. 
Overall, FMS earnings decreased due to lower used vehicle sales and commercial rental results, partially offset by higher full service lease results and reduced overhead spending. Earnings before taxes in FMS decreased 11%. FMS earnings as a percent of operating revenue were 11.3%, down 150 basis points from the prior year. Used vehicle sales performance negatively impacted year-over-year EBT margin percent by 230 basis points.
I'll turn now to dedicated transportation on Page 8. Total revenue grew by 15% and operating revenue was up 7% due to increased volumes, new business and higher pricing. We continue to see strong revenue growth in dedicated, driven primarily by upselling our current lease customers, which represent about 2/3 of our dedicated revenue growth. We're also seeing growth with customers that are new to outsourcing. In fact, over half of our new customers are outsourcing for the first time. DTS earnings increased 32%, primarily due to revenue growth. Segment earnings before taxes as a percent of operating revenue were 8.9%, up 170 basis points from the prior year.
I'll turn now to Supply Chain Solutions on Page 9. Total and operating revenue growth both grew 8% due to new business and increased volumes. SCS earnings before tax were up 16%, primarily resulting from this revenue growth. Segment earnings before tax as a percent of operating revenue were 9% for the quarter, up 70 basis points from the prior year.
At this point, I'll turn the call over to our CFO, Art Garcia, to cover several items, including capital spending.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Robert. Turning to Page 10. Year-to-date gross capital expenditures totaled $1.4 billion, down $700 million from the prior year. This decrease primarily reflects lower planned investments in our rental fleet, lower expected lease fleet growth and
componenttext:
Thanks, Robert. Turning to Page 10. Year-to-date gross capital expenditures totaled $1.4 billion, down $700 million from the prior year. This decrease primarily reflects lower planned investments in our rental fleet, lower expected lease fleet growth and the redeployment of used vehicles to fulfill lease contracts. We realized proceeds primarily from the sale of revenue-earning equipment of $338 million, up $17 million from the prior year. The increase primarily reflects 3% higher sales volumes, partially offset by 8% lower used vehicle pricing. Net capital expenditures decreased by about $700 million to $1.1 billion. 
Turning to the next page. We generated cash from operating activities of almost $1.2 billion year-to-date, up 11%. The increase was driven primarily by higher cash-based earnings and lower working capital requirements, partially offset by higher pension contributions. We generated about $1.6 billion of total cash year-to-date, up $140 million from the prior year. Cash payments for capital expenditures decreased by $600 million to $1.5 billion year-to-date. The company's free cash flow is positive $72 million year-to-date versus the prior year of negative $644 million, reflecting lower capital expenditures and higher operating cash flow. We are maintaining our full year 2016 forecast for free cash flow of positive $200 million.
Page 12 addresses our debt-to-equity position. Total debt of $5.5 billion is basically flat with year-end 2015. Debt-to-equity at the end of the third quarter decreased to 263% from 277% at the end of 2015 and is within our target range of 225% to 275%.
Despite a stronger free cash flow outlook versus prior year, year-end debt-to-equity is expected to be higher than previously forecast due to the continuing pension impact to equity from lower interest rates. We now anticipate year-end debt-to-equity of 265%, up 10 percentage points higher than our most recent forecast. The table highlights the expected pension impact at year-end. We now estimate that pension will increase leverage by 64 percentage points, the largest impact in recent years. 
Equity at the end of the quarter was just under $2.1 billion, up $110 million from year-end 2015, primarily due to earnings, partially offset by foreign exchange and dividends.
At this point, I'll hand the call back over to Robert to provide an asset management update.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Art. Page 14 summarizes key results for our asset management area. Used vehicle inventory held for sale was 7,500 vehicles at quarter end. These exclude the increased number of lease vehicles being prepared for sale that I mentioned earlier. Inclu
componenttext:
Thanks, Art. Page 14 summarizes key results for our asset management area. Used vehicle inventory held for sale was 7,500 vehicles at quarter end. These exclude the increased number of lease vehicles being prepared for sale that I mentioned earlier. Including these vehicles for comparison purposes would increase our used vehicle inventory to approximately 9,000 units, which is up 2,900 vehicles year-over-year and down 100 vehicles sequentially. This is above our normal target of 6,000 to 8,000 used vehicles. We sold 4,000 used vehicles during the quarter, down by 9% from the prior year and down 22% sequentially. While we were able to maintain price, sales volumes were short of our target for the quarter. 
Proceeds per vehicle sold were down 13% for tractors and up 2% for trucks compared to a year ago. From a sequential standpoint, tractor pricing was only down 1% and truck pricing was up 2%. As compared to peak prices realized in the second quarter of 2015, overall used prices were down 11%. This was driven primarily by used tractor pricing, which was down 16% and, to a much lesser extent, truck pricing, which was down 2%. 
The number of leased vehicles that were extended beyond their original lease term increased versus last year by around 730 units year-to-date, but was similar to the levels in the prior few years. 
Vehicles redeployed into other applications increased significantly to almost 4,000 units year-to-date. This reflects our actions to place excess rental vehicles into lease and dedicated contracts as we downsized our rental fleet. Early termination of lease vehicles increased by about 1,000 units this year, primarily reflecting a couple of significant customer bankruptcies. 
I'll now turn to Page 16 to cover our outlook for the fourth quarter of 2016. During the third quarter, we continued to focus on mitigating the impact of a challenging environment in rental and used vehicle sales while growing our contractual businesses and managing overhead costs. Our contractual products, full service lease dedicated and supply chain, all generated revenue growth of 7% or more in the quarter. Rental performance improved as a result of the fleet rightsizing work we did earlier in the year, while favorable overhead performance helped us to offset the impact of lower-than-expected used vehicle sales volumes. 
In full service lease, we grew the fleet by approximately 3,700 vehicles year-to-date after adjusting for an increased number of vehicles being prepared for sale, as mentioned earlier. As such, we're on track to achieve our full year lease fleet growth forecast of 4,000 vehicles. We're also pleased that around 40% of our new lease vehicles added this year have come from customers outsourcing for the first time. 
In rental, utilization comparisons improved significantly versus those realized in the first half of the year. This reflects the actions that we took in the first half to rightsize the rental fleet and the fact that demand was in line with our expectations for the third quarter. Rental pricing was stable and generally in line with our expectation. 
Looking ahead, we continue to expect rental demand to be down 9% for the full year. In light of this, we continue to expect our rental fleet to decline by 11% year-over-year at year-end and by 8% on average. Since we've rightsized the fleet for the current environment, we anticipate that utilization will remain within our long-term targeted range and that global rental pricing will remain generally flat in the fourth quarter. 
In used vehicle sales, the overall environment continues to be very challenging. Pricing has been in line with our expectations, but volumes have been lower than anticipated. Going forward, we'll continue to balance price and volume in order to maximize sales proceeds at the same time, managing inventory levels to be near our target range. 
In supply chain, we continue to expect mid-single-digit operating revenue growth with generally stable margins in the fourth quarter. 
In dedicated, operating revenue is expected to grow by high single digits for the full year, although we expect a somewhat lower year-over-year growth rate in the fourth quarter due to the timing of new sales. We also expect favorable year-over-year margin comparisons to continue in dedicated. 
Given these factors, we're reducing our full year comparable earnings per share forecast to $5.70 to $5.85 from $5.90 to $6.05, primarily to reflect our reduced outlook for used vehicle sales results. Given the shortfall in used vehicle sales volumes in the third quarter, we're expanding the range of our fourth quarter estimate to account for some additional wholesaling activity, which may be necessary to maintain inventories near our target range. The fourth quarter comparable earnings per share forecast is $1.35 to $1.50 versus the prior year of $1.66.
That concludes our prepared remarks this morning. At this time, I'll turn it over to the operator to open up the line for questions. [Operator Instructions]

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttextpreview: So I just wanted to get a little bit more color on used vehicle sales in 4Q if maybe you could talk to the expected volume, the amount of trucks and tractors you're looking to sell in the fourth quarter, what are the expectations for proceeds? And then, I
componenttext: So I just wanted to get a little bit more color on used vehicle sales in 4Q if maybe you could talk to the expected volume, the amount of trucks and tractors you're looking to sell in the fourth quarter, what are the expectations for proceeds? And then, I guess, what I'm looking for is what should -- how should we be thinking about gains on sales all-in for 4Q?

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Matt, if you look at -- in terms of volumes, and let's talk about trucks because it's primarily where the challenges. We're looking to be up a little bit from what we sold in the third quarter in terms of total volumes, maybe a couple hundred of uni
componenttext: Well, Matt, if you look at -- in terms of volumes, and let's talk about trucks because it's primarily where the challenges. We're looking to be up a little bit from what we sold in the third quarter in terms of total volumes, maybe a couple hundred of units. If you look at the high end of the range that we gave you, we're looking to be up slightly in terms of volume. In terms of how to look at it for the fourth quarter, if you look at the net gains for used vehicle sales in the third quarter, we're probably looking at a couple million dollars in the quarter. So we're looking to be somewhere around that to flattish in the fourth quarter -- I'm sorry, in the high end of the scenario. So the range that we've given you is depending on how much volume we could move in the fourth quarter. And if we see an opportunity to move more volume, we're going to look to wholesale some more units possibly, and that'll get us down to the lower end of the range. In that case, we would be moving more units than the 4,300.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a little bit about the Supply Chain Solutions segment, strong growth in the auto and industrial sectors. How much there came from new business wins versus just more volume from existing customers?
componenttext: Just a little bit about the Supply Chain Solutions segment, strong growth in the auto and industrial sectors. How much there came from new business wins versus just more volume from existing customers?

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you look -- David, this is Steve. If you look at auto, it was primarily new business. We did see some volume. As you know, we deal with the majority of the OEMs here in the U.S. and focused on North America, so we see that continuing here for the
componenttext: Yes, if you look -- David, this is Steve. If you look at auto, it was primarily new business. We did see some volume. As you know, we deal with the majority of the OEMs here in the U.S. and focused on North America, so we see that continuing here for the short term.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: And on the industrial side?

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Industrial, really the same message. Majority new business and got a good healthy pipeline right now. We're working on closing some contracts and should carry on here for the next short term.
componenttext: Industrial, really the same message. Majority new business and got a good healthy pipeline right now. We're working on closing some contracts and should carry on here for the next short term.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just to follow up on the SCS business. Do lower truck rates because truck pricing in general, specifically the truckload market has been very soft this year. Does that help SCS margins at all? Does it hurt SCS margins? How do you think about that
componenttext: And then just to follow up on the SCS business. Do lower truck rates because truck pricing in general, specifically the truckload market has been very soft this year. Does that help SCS margins at all? Does it hurt SCS margins? How do you think about that?

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I would say right now, what we're seeing is some new growth in our transportation management service offering. We are seeing some growth as well in dedicated, but not really a direct correlation in the used truck pricing.
componenttext: No, I would say right now, what we're seeing is some new growth in our transportation management service offering. We are seeing some growth as well in dedicated, but not really a direct correlation in the used truck pricing.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, David, on that, I would just add that the truckload rates, for example, that we manage for transportation management is typically passed through. The lower rates will be passed through the customer. We're just getting the management fee on it.
componenttext: I think, David, on that, I would just add that the truckload rates, for example, that we manage for transportation management is typically passed through. The lower rates will be passed through the customer. We're just getting the management fee on it.

componenttext: I was just thinking if you got a percentage fee at the lower rate then you're going to get less income.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Casey Deak of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question is from Casey Deak of Wells Fargo.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Had a quick question on dedicated. The 50% of new customers in there are coming from -- are new customers that are new to outsourcing. Can you talk a little bit about the profile? Or is that -- are those typical dedicated accounts? What size fleets are yo
componenttext: Had a quick question on dedicated. The 50% of new customers in there are coming from -- are new customers that are new to outsourcing. Can you talk a little bit about the profile? Or is that -- are those typical dedicated accounts? What size fleets are you looking at and the like?

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is John. The typical customer we're seeing that's new to outsourcing, many of which are existing FMS private fleet operators, right, that they lease equipment from us. So if you look at where the growth has been coming, it has been coming from u
componenttext: Yes. This is John. The typical customer we're seeing that's new to outsourcing, many of which are existing FMS private fleet operators, right, that they lease equipment from us. So if you look at where the growth has been coming, it has been coming from upselling from lease and to dedicated. And then when you look at the profile that customer base, they're typically in that 15 to 20-plus trucks that are operating their own fleet and are finding it challenging to keep up with the rising costs of equipment, also finding it tough to outfit their fleets with the right drivers and deliver for their customers. So a lot of the success we continue to see is through upselling from our FMS accounts and lease accounts into dedicated.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So to make sure I understand that correctly. If -- so I'm thinking about it as they're new to outsourcing as they're not currently in the Ryder System, not FMS customers. Is that incorrect?
componenttext: Okay. So to make sure I understand that correctly. If -- so I'm thinking about it as they're new to outsourcing as they're not currently in the Ryder System, not FMS customers. Is that incorrect?

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, new to outsourcing means they haven't outsourced their private fleet operations. So they might be leasing trucks from us, but they still have their own drivers and manage their own private fleet on their own. It's considered still to be insourced, if
componenttext: No, new to outsourcing means they haven't outsourced their private fleet operations. So they might be leasing trucks from us, but they still have their own drivers and manage their own private fleet on their own. It's considered still to be insourced, if you will, from a private fleet or dedicated standpoint.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ben Hartford FBR.
componenttext: The next question is from Ben Hartford FBR.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Robert, the discussion around the gains in the fourth quarter makes sense, but maybe you could talk about 2017 or just the risk to that line item turning negative, turning into a loss. What is the likelihood of that as perhaps as you see the current envir
componenttext: Robert, the discussion around the gains in the fourth quarter makes sense, but maybe you could talk about 2017 or just the risk to that line item turning negative, turning into a loss. What is the likelihood of that as perhaps as you see the current environment playing out? What is the likelihood that we can see that line item turn into a loss on sales this cycle?

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ben. It's still probably a little early to tell. We're in the process of putting together our business plan and our forecast, so we still got a lot of work to do to get to that. But clearly, we've had a lot of headwind this year in used vehicle sales
componenttext: Yes, Ben. It's still probably a little early to tell. We're in the process of putting together our business plan and our forecast, so we still got a lot of work to do to get to that. But clearly, we've had a lot of headwind this year in used vehicle sales, and we had $100 million in gains last year. And this year, we're probably looking at $30 million, $30-something million by the time it's all said and done. So what I can tell you is that I would expect next year's headwind is going to be meaningfully less. But is it going to be breakeven or is it going to be somewhat negative? We still don't know. It really depends on how the market here evolves over the next quarter, next several quarters and also, some decisions we've got to make here in the fourth quarter of what we want to do with the vehicles that we have in inventory. And are we going to look maybe wholesale some additional units to get the inventories down a little bit. So that's still work to be done.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess, in that same vein, I understand you're still in the process of putting the budget together for '17. But used vehicles prices headwinds should abate, I would imagine full service lease fleet growth will decelerate but remain positive. Yo
componenttext: Okay. And I guess, in that same vein, I understand you're still in the process of putting the budget together for '17. But used vehicles prices headwinds should abate, I would imagine full service lease fleet growth will decelerate but remain positive. You've got [indiscernible] on the contract side. We've got to think about residual values and the impact in DNA. I guess that's all set up for thinking about 2017 EPS. I mean, what is the likelihood that we should see growth in 2017 EPS as it stands today given kind of a preliminary take on some of the headwinds and tailwinds?

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're kind of reeling me in here. But I think if you look at the negatives that we had this year, the headwinds he had this year will be less. There's still be probably headwinds. I expect rental to be a headwind in the first half and then get a little b
componenttext: You're kind of reeling me in here. But I think if you look at the negatives that we had this year, the headwinds he had this year will be less. There's still be probably headwinds. I expect rental to be a headwind in the first half and then get a little bit get better in the second half because of the rightsizing of the feet. Used vehicle sales should be less headwind, but again, it'll still be a headwind next year unless the market turns. And I think right now, most people are seeing this used truck market is going to be around for a little bit, a little bit longer certainly. The positives, we're going to have growth. I'm still expecting growth across all the contractual businesses. The growth is probably going to be less than what we had this year, primarily in FSL and FMS, primarily the headwind on less OEM production that's being forecasted now. And in dedicated and supply chains, a little bit of the timing of new sales. But I still expect positive contributions from each of those. We are -- we are not going to have the same depreciation benefit that we had this year. We're not going to have -- we don't expect to have a depreciation benefit at all. So that was $40 million of tailwind that we had this year that we shouldn't have next year. So that's kind of how it's all coming together as we start to look at it. But again, there's still a lot of work to be done around overhead cost actions that we're going to look at and take and some of the other things around new products and things that could also help us. So the cake is not baked yet. And obviously, our goal is always to try to get -- make us much of the headwind up as we can. But there are still going to be some meaningful headwind going into 2017.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Scott Group of Wolfe Research.
componenttext: The next question is from Scott Group of Wolfe Research.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So that was -- that last question was helpful. Just a couple just follow-ups on that, Robert. So the -- are you thinking that residual value is a push next year? Or could it actually be a headwind next year? And then just on the idea of less leasing fleet
componenttext: So that was -- that last question was helpful. Just a couple just follow-ups on that, Robert. So the -- are you thinking that residual value is a push next year? Or could it actually be a headwind next year? And then just on the idea of less leasing fleet growth, maybe could you just put some sensitivity around like, let's say, we have 1,000 fewer units of leasing fleet growth what that means for free cash flow?

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tell me the first part of the question now.
componenttext: Tell me the first part of the question now.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on residual value, I think you said that you're not expecting any benefit. But is there risk that, that could be a headwind next year?
componenttext: So on residual value, I think you said that you're not expecting any benefit. But is there risk that, that could be a headwind next year?

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would tell you as we sit here today, we see it at best, like we said, a push for next year. I guess it's possible. It would depend on, I guess, some significant pricing declines into Q4, which we were not really contemplating right now. So my thoug
componenttext: Yes, I would tell you as we sit here today, we see it at best, like we said, a push for next year. I guess it's possible. It would depend on, I guess, some significant pricing declines into Q4, which we were not really contemplating right now. So my thought is we're kind of around -- right around that push. I mean, you may be a little bit negative at worst, I guess, as we sit here today. That would be our view on that. The other area around free cash flow, 1,000 units of lease fleet growth, that obviously, we don't buy 1,000 units. That's going to be $80 million to $100 million of lower CapEx.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay. Yes, I just think that sensitivity is helpful. And then just last question, if I look in the back of the deck on redeployments and extensions and all that, some pretty big increases there versus trend. What's that telling you about the market
componenttext: Okay. Okay. Yes, I just think that sensitivity is helpful. And then just last question, if I look in the back of the deck on redeployments and extensions and all that, some pretty big increases there versus trend. What's that telling you about the market relative kind of how you've been thinking about it?

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we'll start with redeployments. Redeployments talked about that in the prepared remarks. It's up primarily due to the all the redeployment of rental equipment. As you know, we had the strategy to take rental units and redeployment them to lea
componenttext: Yes, I think we'll start with redeployments. Redeployments talked about that in the prepared remarks. It's up primarily due to the all the redeployment of rental equipment. As you know, we had the strategy to take rental units and redeployment them to lease and dedicated applications. That's really the majority of that increase. Around the extensions, you have some increase, but again, it's not outside of our normal historical rates. That is a lever that we may pull going into 2017 and do more extensions in order to keep units from coming -- more units from coming to the UTC, so there could be some marginal increase in that going into next year. And then early terminations, as I mentioned, was really primarily a couple off bankruptcies that we had, customer bankruptcies or credit pulls to that we had to take vehicles back. These are primarily customers that were in trucking-related business or the for higher carriers. And we took those units back and also those units got redeployed. So that's really what's driving that.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Justin Long of Stephens.
componenttext: The next question is from Justin Long of Stephens.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question I had, last quarter, you talked about your guidance assuming $1.30 EPS headwind this year from a combination of used vehicle sales and commercial rental. And I think you said the headwind was split roughly half and half between those 2 cate
componenttext: First question I had, last quarter, you talked about your guidance assuming $1.30 EPS headwind this year from a combination of used vehicle sales and commercial rental. And I think you said the headwind was split roughly half and half between those 2 categories. Could you update what that number is and as it relates to the new guidance?

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's about $1.50 now, and I'm thinking about the high end of the range is about $1.50. And it's a little bit more weighted now towards used vehicle sales. So as you know, used vehicle sales in the forecast I mentioned, got worse than from our previou
componenttext: Yes, it's about $1.50 now, and I'm thinking about the high end of the range is about $1.50. And it's a little bit more weighted now towards used vehicle sales. So as you know, used vehicle sales in the forecast I mentioned, got worse than from our previous forecast. And we also took a little bit extra gas in terms of less volume in Q3.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. That's helpful. And then I also wanted to ask about rental utilization. If you look at the sequential trend, we saw an improvement, and that's different than what we've seen in the past few years where rental utilization has declined sequenti
componenttext: Okay. Great. That's helpful. And then I also wanted to ask about rental utilization. If you look at the sequential trend, we saw an improvement, and that's different than what we've seen in the past few years where rental utilization has declined sequentially in the third quarter. Could you just talk about how you're thinking about the trend in utilization going forward? And also how this could impact margins given rental tends to be a higher-margin business?

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's really a positive part of the story, the good work that Dennis and his team did in the first half of the year and really rapidly rightsizing that fleet to get utilization levels really back up to the levels that we like to see, back up
componenttext: Yes, I think that's really a positive part of the story, the good work that Dennis and his team did in the first half of the year and really rapidly rightsizing that fleet to get utilization levels really back up to the levels that we like to see, back up over 76%. So I think as you look at the margin impact of a dropping demand, we probably saw the worst of it in Q2, where really we still had too many units in the fleet during the middle of that quarter, and we had lost the revenue. Now we've rightsized the fleet, so basically, the pull-through -- the negative pull-through has been minimized. It's going to be at that least to rental margin percentage, somewhere in the 30-plus [ph] percent level where you're going to get negative pull-through on the lost revenue. That should catch the tail sometime in the middle of next year. We start to see then some year-over-year improvements.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Brian Ossenbeck of JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question is from Brian Ossenbeck of JPMorgan.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the expense side, Robert, you mentioned lower-than-expected overhead spend. Can you characterize what that was and perhaps quantify some offset here in the quarter? Sounds like it's perhaps structural, so any more details on that and what you coul
componenttext: Just on the expense side, Robert, you mentioned lower-than-expected overhead spend. Can you characterize what that was and perhaps quantify some offset here in the quarter? Sounds like it's perhaps structural, so any more details on that and what you could see in that area going forward to offset some of the weakness here in the transactional side of the business?

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you remember of the beginning of year, we had a number waterfall chart, we had $0.38 of overhead actions that we took in January of this year to really help offset some of the earnings shortfall. So we are realizing all of that, and that's helping
componenttext: Yes, if you remember of the beginning of year, we had a number waterfall chart, we had $0.38 of overhead actions that we took in January of this year to really help offset some of the earnings shortfall. So we are realizing all of that, and that's helping us on a year-over-year comparison. In the third quarter, we had a little additional -- we had some additional benefit from -- it was kind of numerous things such as commissions and bonus and a few other things that really made it a little bit more than what we had expected. So that's really what makes up that delta. We don't expect those items necessarily to recur in the fourth quarter, so that's why there's some of that decline in the guidance. Obviously, along with the reduced expectations, the lowered expectations around used vehicle sales.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So little bit north of the $0.38 on a full year basis sounds about when you're implying here?
componenttext: Okay. So little bit north of the $0.38 on a full year basis sounds about when you're implying here?

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brian. It's north of that, but I wouldn't call these related to those cost actions that Robert was referring to. I think these were just general items that came in lower than what we had forecasted at the beginning.
componenttext: Yes, Brian. It's north of that, but I wouldn't call these related to those cost actions that Robert was referring to. I think these were just general items that came in lower than what we had forecasted at the beginning.

componenttext: Yes, I'll give you an example. Bonus would actually fall into the bucket that we call compensation. So compensation is going to be less of a headwind than what we had originally expected because we're paying out less bonus.

componenttext: Well, no, our guidance had been around $200 million.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Yes, no, it's pretty much in line with. We generate over $400 million from cash flow from ops, still should generate close to $100 million in proceeds from used truck sales. And then the cash CapEx is around $400 million for [indiscernible].

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the other thing is remember, we spent $90 million this year on rental, and that's done at the beginning of year. So you get that headwind in the first half of the year in terms of free cash flow, and now you're -- the second half is where you generate
componenttext: And the other thing is remember, we spent $90 million this year on rental, and that's done at the beginning of year. So you get that headwind in the first half of the year in terms of free cash flow, and now you're -- the second half is where you generate more just normal seasonality, I would say.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Todd Fowler of KeyBanc.
componenttext: The next question is from Todd Fowler of KeyBanc.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, in the guidance, maybe you said this just for clarification, if I missed it, what would the expectation be for the used vehicle inventory the end of the year based on your guidance range is it did you get down to or did you get to the high end of
componenttext: I guess, in the guidance, maybe you said this just for clarification, if I missed it, what would the expectation be for the used vehicle inventory the end of the year based on your guidance range is it did you get down to or did you get to the high end of the range so 9,000 now comes to 8,000? Or do you get into like the mid part of the range? I'm just trying to get a sense of where the inventory would be at the end of the year. Go ahead.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can't pin down exactly. We have the range on the earnings guidance. But no, we're probably end up still above the target range, above the 8,000. It's just a matter we don't want to get too far above it. So we ended up, if you really look at comparable n
componenttext: I can't pin down exactly. We have the range on the earnings guidance. But no, we're probably end up still above the target range, above the 8,000. It's just a matter we don't want to get too far above it. So we ended up, if you really look at comparable numbers, we were ended the quarter -- the third quarter at 9,000 units. So that was done 100 units from the second quarter. So what we're going to this probably be in that range, maybe a little bit lower, depending on how much we are able to decide to wholesale. So what we're trying to do is make sure we don't get too far above where we're at right now. We want to stay within striking distance of that 8,000, and that's really the game plan as we go into Q4. Again, unless the market changes and we have an opportunity to do more.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I was thinking about a little bit is going into 2017 and how much inventory you're going to have on hand if it makes more sense to move it now versus waiting into next year. This gets into the second part of the question. When do you take the write-d
componenttext: What I was thinking about a little bit is going into 2017 and how much inventory you're going to have on hand if it makes more sense to move it now versus waiting into next year. This gets into the second part of the question. When do you take the write-downs? I mean, so the 1,500 trucks in the fourth quarter that we're sitting in the lease fleet when you mark those down to what you think the sale value is? Did you do that in the third quarter? Is that something that won't happen until the fourth quarter if you need to do that?

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we expect those -- that higher level of units being prepared for sale to continue for several quarters because we're really not in a hurry to go out and get these units out to the UPC. We've got plenty of units to sell. So I don't see that as necessa
componenttext: Yes, we expect those -- that higher level of units being prepared for sale to continue for several quarters because we're really not in a hurry to go out and get these units out to the UPC. We've got plenty of units to sell. So I don't see that as necessarily as a fourth quarter probably bleed in over the next several quarters. But to your earlier point on the opportunity to bring the inventory down, we're in agreement with that. The issue just becomes what's the trade-off of price versus volume. And there's times when no matter how much you lower, you're not going to get the volume. So what we've been doing is just trying to keep that balance. And if we can -- if we see an opportunity and we see that the market is there, you're going to see us try to move more units and get into that range. It's just we're trying to be prudent about what that opportunity might be at this point.

headline: Ryder System, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
